description.narrative: Promote peaceful agreement on democratic reform, rules, and frameworks. Promote peaceful, broad-based participation in determining, defining, and negotiating changes to governing structures. Illustrative examples include promoting inclusive consensus-building processes related to peace agreements, national dialogues, referenda on key issues, and constitutional development or reform. Programs are designed to incorporate and support mechanisms that advance conflict mediation, resolution and negotiation of disputes in the context of these processes.

title.narrative: Conflict Early Warning, Mitigation and Peace Building

description.narrative: Reduce the threat or impact of violent conflict and promote peaceful resolution of differences, ensure conflict sensitivity so as not to exacerbate sources of violence and/or establish an inclusive framework for peace and reconciliation which addresses all key drivers and mitigators of conflict. This includes activities aimed specifically at atrocities prevention, as well as activities intended to transform relationships to decrease the likelihood of future violent conflict. Develop and support early warning and response mechanisms such as early warning models and response protocols; conflict analysis; monitoring mechanisms and peace structures at different levels; peace building communication systems; confidence-building measures; crisis-response planning and management skills at the local and national levels; and means for rapid and effective response in the event of crisis. Support quick-impact, outcome-based activities required to demonstrate the positive impact of a peace process, operation or other event, such as mobilizing small grants for communities and local/national governments; ensuring delivery of services (e.g., "ministry in a box"); bringing local and national government authorities closer to their constituencies (e.g., town hall meetings, consultations, production and dissemination of information); generating employment for potential spoilers; and managing expectations.

description.narrative: Administrative costs and operating expenses of USAID contributing to Advisory and Assistance Services.

Reduce the threat or impact of violent conflict and promote the peaceful resolution of differences, mitigate violence if it has already broken out, or establish a framework for peace and reconciliation. This is done by identifying the causes of conflict and state failure; supporting early responses that address the causes and consequences of instability and conflict; and developing long lasting solutions to the problems that drive conflict. This includes support for processes and mechanisms for reconciliation and conflict mitigation no matter what the source of the conflict may be, though this may require integration with other elements.

description.narrative: USAID Achieve will build local vocational training providers capacities to support vulnerable youth in Thailands Deep South increasing their skills, knowledge and experience necessary for improved economic opportunity. In this way, it will address a key conflict driver and offer young people a way out of the cycle of criminality and violence. By integrating a people-to-people approach at all levels of project management and activities, USAID Achieve will foster mutual understanding, trust and concrete cooperation between youth and between key people and government.

description.narrative: (Thailand): .The USAID Together activity will support civil society-led conflict mitigation efforts to reduce drivers of latent and violent conflict in Thailand. This activity will complement people-to-people reconciliation activities funded by USAID's Office of Conflict Management and Mitigation. With FY 2020 funds, this activity will support collaboration among Royal Thai Government agencies, civil society organizations, and local communities to promote meaningful engagement and peaceful dialogue, and strengthen their capacity to mitigate conflict by addressing citizens' needs and grievances. For example, the activity will work with government agencies to improve the capacity of their existing mechanisms for receiving input/feedback from citizens. USAID Together will also catalyze local actors towards action by enhancing their awareness and knowledge of how to achieve reconciliation in their communities. It will work with civil society organizations to improve their capacity to advocate for the public interest, find common solutions with the Royal Thai Government through non-violent means, and aim to improve relations and constructive dialogue among citizens of different backgrounds in local communities..

title.narrative: USAID Building University-Industry Learning and Development through Innovation and Technology Alliance (BUILD-IT)

description.narrative: (Vietnam): The BUILD-IT Alliance is a new.education alliance among government, industry, and academic partners in the.U.S. and Vietnam. The goal is to link science, technology, engineering, and.math (STEM) instruction in Vietnamese universities with the needs and.capabilities of companies. .With FY16 funds, BUILD-IT will organize.a student industry fair, higher education executive policy workshops, a women.in technology forum, and introduce applied curriculum models. .BUILD-IT will help Vietnamese.university students lead inclusive, technology-based growth by.engaging leadership in strengthening higher education policy; enable.university-private sector collaboration; develop curricular partnerships,.mentorships, and industry-sponsored opportunities to build students'.professional and technical competencies in preparation for STEM careers; and.improve academic programs and outcomes..

description.narrative: (Thailand): The Sapan governance program aims to enhance the capacity of civil society organizations (CSOs), support collaboration between CSOs and the Thai Government-particularly independent agencies-to build participatory democracy, and mitigate social tensions in Thailand. FY 2014 funding will continue to provide experts, technical assistance, and training to raise awareness among Thai citizens about their responsibilities to promote good governance and citizen action. As part of that effort, the activity will strengthen CSO institutional, governance, technical, and advocacy capacities; increase the visibility of advocacy non-governmental organizations and civic leaders working to promote peace; and improve the capacities of journalists to cover policy and conflict issues. The activity will also support a number of dialogues focusing on issues of importance in democratic societies as well as on the work of the independent agencies on transparency and accountability issues.

description.narrative: Provide goods, personnel, services and assistance to meet basic human needs in order to foster transition from relief according to principles of universality, impartiality and human dignity. This element should be done, when possible, as part of an integrated, coordinated and/or multi-sectoral approach.

This element should be done, when possible, as part of an integrated, coordinated and/or multi-sectoral approach.

Improve the ability of the USG, host countries and other partners to prepare for and mitigate the effects of disasters, including both natural disasters and complex emergencies, taking into account the differences in men and womens freedom of movement and access to information. Activities under this component include any efforts to enhance the capacities of the USG (in Washington and in the field), humanitarian assistance providers, national host-country authorities, and local communities to engage in disaster reduction and response activities. Activities consist of standardized and coordinated assessments, monitoring, information sharing, data and situational analysis, joint planning; enhancement of coping mechanisms, including the capacity to address adaptation to constantly changing situations on the ground including climate variability and climate change.

(Thailand): .The USAID Thailand Counter Trafficking in Persons (CTIP) activity follows the "4Ps" paradigm of Prevention, Protection, Prosecution, and Partnerships to reduce Trafficking in Persons (TIP) and better protect the rights of trafficked persons in Thailand. With FY 2022 funds, the USAID Thailand CTIP activity will work with the Royal Thai Government (RTG), civil society organizations (CSOs), the private sector, media, academia, and at-risk communities to strengthen their capacity and collaboration to combat TIP. The activity will coordinate and complement USG-supported CTIP programs in Thailand, including the U.S. State Department's Office to Monitor and Combat TIP, Bureau for International Narcotics and Law Enforcement, Federal Bureau of Investigation, and Homeland Security Investigations. Moreover, it will seek to collaborate with other donors and international organizations to support the efforts of CTIP stakeholders in Thailand. The activity is committed to mainstreaming a gender and social inclusion approach in all interventions and employing innovative, data-driven solutions-both technical and programmatic-through research and technologies to address emerging issues related to TIP. The USAID Thailand CTIP activity will prioritize areas where there is increased risk of human trafficking, including border areas, locations with high concentration of migrant workers, vulnerable populations, existence of government shelters, and priority industries (fishing, construction, agriculture, and domestic work)..

description.narrative: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs). Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

person-name.narrative: Zach Child, Regional Desk Officer, East Asia

description.narrative: Develop and conduct needs assessments, baseline studies, targeted evaluations, special studies or other information-gathering efforts specifically for the design, monitoring and evaluation of USG-funded programs. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned, testing demonstration and/or pilot models, or the preparation of strategic plans and other short-term programming tasks. Note: All such activities that are carried out by partners as an integral part of their monitoring and evaluation efforts for programs funded under other sub-elements should be included within those sub-elements.
